keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, is under pressure from within his own party to drop out.

John Catsimatidis, a prominent Republican supermarket magnate and owner of WABC radio, publicly urged Sliwa to withdraw, citing loyalty and the need for Sliwa to 'love New York more than anything else'.
Republican figures, including Andrew Cuomo (running as an independent), are attempting to consolidate opposition to Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani by pushing Sliwa out of the race.
Sliwa has responded strongly, rejecting the idea that billionaire donors or Cuomo can dictate who should run, emphasizing his representation of blue-collar working-class voters.
Sliwa dismissed criticisms from Andrew Cuomo and Bill Ackman, calling out their influence and claiming they have the power to 'determine' the next mayor.
President Donald Trump mocked Sliwa, calling him 'not exactly primetime' and referencing his cat-related public persona, showing broader Republican skepticism.
Zohran Mamdani has aligned with Sliwa in opposing the idea of billionaire-dominated politics, suggesting they are united in their belief that New Yorkers should vote freely.

Despite the efforts of major Republican figures to sideline Sliwa, he has remained defiant and is continuing to campaign, maintaining that he represents a distinct political voice in the city's governance.
The article highlights a growing tension within the Republican base over whether to support a moderate, establishment figure like Cuomo or a grassroots, working-class candidate like Sliwa.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican mayoral candidate in New York City, is under increasing pressure from within the party to drop out, notably from his boss John Catsimatidis, who owns WABC radio and publicly urged him to step back. The pressure comes amid efforts by Republican figures, including former governor Andrew Cuomo and investor Bill Ackman, to consolidate opposition to Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani by pushing Sliwa out. Sliwa has rejected these efforts, defending his candidacy as representing working-class voters and criticizing billionaire donors and establishment politics. President Donald Trump has mocked Sliwa, calling him unimpressive and focused on cats, further signaling Republican skepticism. Despite this, Sliwa remains active in the race, and Mamdani has aligned with him to oppose elite-driven politics, creating a surprising political alliance that challenges the traditional power structures in New York’s mayoral race.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
